--- title: Pyramidalis Muscle subtitle: Anterior abdominal wall muscle --- ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Abdominal muscles @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 ::: ::: {#tbl-pyramidalis-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Warning: No 'path' link found for variable 'nan' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'None' in YAML data. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Pyramidalis T12 Tenses linea alba
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Pubis (anterior to rectus abdominis) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020. # Insertion {#insertion} The pyramidalis runs within the rectus sheath to insert on the *linea alba* @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020. # Innervation {#innervation} The pyramidalis is innervated by the [Subcostal n.]({{< var ref-subcostal-nerve.path >}}) with origins from the [T12]({{< var ref-nerve-root.t12 >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020. # Action {#action} In a literal sense the linea alba "tenses" the linea alba [@gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020; @jonesProjectFoundations2025]. # Overview The muscle is only present in 80% of the population @jonesProjectFoundations2025 and can even be absent in one or both sides @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {.callout-note} If the pyramidalis is absent, the [rectus abdominis]({{< var ref-rectus-abdominis.path >}}) will adjust and increase its size. :::
